messages.content: Case Title: Load rating for BLP01 variable height optical post. Question: I see that the BLP01 optical post has a load capacity of 500 lbs. I also see that it can be adjusted by turning the “SM1” 1.035-40 threads. Does the load rating only apply for static loads or can you adjust the height while it is bearing a load? Do you have a maximum load rating for when the height is being adjusted?

The 500 lbs load capacity is for static loads when the height is locked in place by its knurled locking ring. The BLP01 must be able to rotate to adjust its height. If one end is secure any components attached to the rotating end will also rotate as the height is adjusted. Without the locking ring, the only thing holding the height of the BLP01 in place is the friction of the SM1 threads. It would mainly be up to the user to bear the load (or simply remove it) when adjusting the height, though there is also 0.23" OD thru hole in the smooth, upper adjustable height portion of the post to apply extra torque when increasing/decreasing the variable height of the post.. Unfortunately we do not spec the amount of weight the BLP01 can hold without the locking ring tightened in place.
Case Title: BKF12 Specs. Question: I would like to know the operating temperature of the material and the damage threshold.

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. While we do not have a formal operating temperature range for BKF12, it has been tested to withstand 1 hour under a lamp at up to 750 F (398.889 C). Please note this is not a formal spec so therefore we can not provide any guarantees. Unfortunately, we do not have any information on the damage threshold for the BKF12. We assume it should be fine for stray light, but we recommend against direct laser contact. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: SM1S15. Question: what are the external threads on this item?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The SM1S15 has SM1 external threads. The specifications of this threading are below: SM1 Threading: Ø1" Lens Tubes, 30 mm Cage Systems
External Thread, 1.035"-40.0 UNS-2A	Internal Thread, 1.035"-40.0 UNS-2B
Max Major Diameter	1.0339"	Min Major Diameter	1.0350"
Min Major Diameter	1.0288"	Min Pitch Diameter	1.0188"
Max Pitch Diameter	1.0177"	Max Pitch Diameter	1.0234"
Min Pitch Diameter	1.0142"	Min Minor Diameter (and 83.3% of Thread)	1.008"
Max Minor Diameter	1.0068"	Max Minor Diameter (and 64.9% of Thread)	1.014"
Case Title: AB90B Inquiry. Question: Can you please check angular tolerance of the right angle brackets, such as AB90B(/M) and email the spec to Daniel from Sagentia Innovation (Cambridge) ?

Thanks for contacting my colleague earlier on the online chat. The perpendicularity tolerance between the two mounting surfaces on AB90B(/M), AB90H(/M) and AB90A(/M) is 0.002" (0.0508 mm). If you would like me to look into any more of the perpendicularity tolerances on other parts please let me know!

Case Title: AB90A Material Question. Question: I’m looking at AP90 Right-Angle Bracket. Your website states it’s machined aluminum. Would it be correct to assume it’s made of Al6061-T6? (Or are you able to tell me the exact alloy and temper?)
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. You are correct, this part is made out of 6061-T6 aluminum. Hopefully this helps. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: KM100. Question: Hi, sorry to trouble you but I was wondering if you could help me out. I was wondering what the turns per inches were for the adjustment screws for the mirror mounts. Would it be possible to find this out or if not, the um/turn for these mirror mounts. Thanks!

there are 80 turns per inch for these screws. The specification can be seen on the "Auto CAD PDF" here: https://www.thorlabs.com/thorproduct.cfm?partnumber=KM100, where 1/4in-80 refers to the major diameter of the screw followed by the threads per inch (TPI).
Case Title: MB15S/M Material Grade. Question: MB15S/M is a passivated stainless steel breadboard. What grade of stainless steel is it?
this specification can be found in the table on the overview page for these breadboards. It is 416 stainless steel.

Case Title: RE: SCP05T suited for high accelerations. Question: We ordered part: POLARIS-K1F1

Is it possible to remove the orange knob?

Thank you in advance.
All three knobs of the POLARIS-K1F1 are removable.
Case Title: LG10 goggles >1100nm. Question: Would you provide specs of LG10 goggles above 1100 nm?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. We unfortunately do not have data for LG10 goggles at wavelengths longer than 1100 nm. However, just about all glasses that are not specified >1100 nm online will have similar typical performances from 1100 - 3000 nm with quite low Optical Densities. I would expect <1 OD for the LG10. Hopefully this helps. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: TB5 - Reflectance NIR. Question: what is the reflection of the material in the region 0.9-1.6 um?
Please find attached the available TB5 measurement as Excel file .
Case Title: Enquiry about the product B2939. Question: I would like to know the material with which this bottle is made.

The closures/nozzles for the “Methanol,” “Isopropanol,” “Acetone,” and “Distilled Water” translucent bottles are made of Polypropylene, while the translucent bottles themselves are made from low-density polyethylene (LDPE).
Case Title: SM16RR Part Tolerances. Question: I was wondering if you have any dimension tolerances for the part SM16RR?
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support! The tolerance on the 0.54" Clear aperture is +/- 0.005" and the tolerance on the 0.041" spanner slots is +0.003/-0.000".
Case Title: ID12Z/M Request *.Step. Question: We bought iris for our lidar test ID12Z/M. Can I get a 3D drawing for the product? (*.Step)
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. Attached please find the requested STP file. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: TAPSM1 drill size. Question: Please advise of correct drill size for this tap.

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. There is no determined tap drill size for creating a pilot hole for SM1 thread; we typically recommend milling out a pilot bore (possibly using a boring bar on an end mill) of Ø1.011" ± 0.003" to begin tapping SM1 threads. Hopefully this helps. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: KM2CE. Question: The schematic drawing specifies an imperial 4-40 NYLON-TIPPED OPTIC SECURING SCREW 0.05in [1.3mm] HEX for securing the optics. Is there not a metric version that uses M3 or M4 setscrews instead?

Thanks for contacting Thorlabs. Unfortunately we do not have a Metric version for the securing screw. Apologies for this. Although we can provide the suitable hex key for this screw https://www.thorlabs.de/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=1407 Hope this helpls and sorry for the inconvenience.

Case Title: specifying the SM05 standard thread in Solidworks. Question: I’m wondering if the “hole wizard” in Solidworks supports this thread type? (0.535”-40). I’m trying to incorporate some of your parts into an assembly, and it’s not obvious to me if the hole-wizard can handle this.
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. Unfortunately, our SM05 threads are not immediately available in SolidWorks. However, you could input the thread specs, which can be found below:

Case Title: Φ​(M) value for ID12Z/M. Question: User is going to buy ID12Z/M(Mounted Zero-Aperture Iris, Ø12.0 mm Max Aperture, TR75/M Post) Related this product, What is the Φ​(M) value of the coupling of Iris and Post?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. Could you please clarify what you mean by Φ​(M) ? If by this you are asking how the aperture and the post are coupled together, then they are coupled via a M4 x 0.7 threaded set screw. The screw used is: Alloy Steel Cup-Point Set Screw, M4 x 0.7 mm Thread, 8 mm Long | McMaster-Carr. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: KAD11F accuracy and precision. Question: Do you have any data on the accuracy and precision of this mount?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. Unfortunately, we have not measured any sort of accuracy or precision specs for this adapter. We apologize for the inconvenience. The only specifications we have really measured are the +/- 6 degrees of travel range and the 24 mrad resolution. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: F3ESN1P. Question: Hello,I have ordered some of these and have read that you recommend using Loctite Anaerobic Adhesive product number 680. However, I cant get hold of any from any reputable supplier i.e. RS components. Please could you recommend alternatives?

Thank you for getting in touch we do offer LOC312 which would work as well but these are also on lead time at the moment due to the supplier being the same. I will get the lead time for this and get back to you.
Case Title: Shelf life article, 11815, LIJM, NORLAND INC.-NBA 107, NBA 107. Question: Can you provide me the shelf life from the article mentioned above.
These UV-curing adhesives have a shelf life of approximately 8 months. This time frame begins on the date the epoxy was packaged at the manufacturer.
Case Title: MB12 tolerances. Question: What are the length and with tolerances/accuracies of this plate?
Thank you for contacting Thorlbs. The length and width of this breadboard are both 12.000" +/- 0.005". Hopefully this helps. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: LMR05-P5 Mounts for 1/2" Lenses. Question: I just purchased the LSA01-A ½” lens kit (https://www.thorlabs.com/thorproduct.cfm?partnumber=LSA01-A) and wanted to check that the LMR05 mounts have the correct threading to mount the lenses. Thank you for your help with this.
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. Yes, these lenses with a 1/2' diameter can be mounted in the LMR05 using the included SM05RR retaining ring. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: Question about maximum torque PRM1. Question: We are mounting some optomechanics onto the screw holes of PRM1. We are wondering what is the maximum torque that we can put onto the rotation mount?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. If you are referring to either the holes meant for cage rods or the locking screw, then we do not have a maximum torque rating. We would suggest hand tightening the optomech in this case. If you are referring to mounting an optic in the mounting aperture itself, we do not have an exact recommended mounting torque, but it would be similar to what we suggest for our 1" Polaris mounts which is about 0.03 to 0.06 N·m. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: Blackout Fabric reflectance plot. Question: I’m interested in the blackout fabric (part number BK5). I noticed that some of the other blackout material has a reflectance plot (wavelength on the x axis and reflectance % on the y axis). Is a similar plot available for the fabric?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs.
 
I have attached the chart that I believe you are looking for, in an excel document.
 
Please let me know if there's anything else I can do to help!
Case Title: XT66SD-250. Question: I am looking for the straightness specification on these rail lengths?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support.
 
The straightness is 0.001 inches.
 
Feel free to contact me if you need more information.

Case Title: Bandwidth of Voice Coil. Question: 
Please let me know the bandwidth (in Hz) of the Voice Coil Actuators VC063 and VC125?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support. We do not spec a bandwidth for these voice coil actuators, however we do spec their resistance and inductance, which will determine the "time constant" (eq. 30/page 27 of this document from Texas Instrument) of the inductor/voice coil. You can think of this like the "rise time" for the coil. This will determine the slew rate/current output you need to look for in a driver to match this time constant. This document also helps find a driver (Page 25 covers driving inductive loads like this). Unfortunately, we don't have a dedicated driver for these yet. Hopefully, this helps.
Case Title: NOA65 & NOA68. Question: I’m curious as to what the temperature range is for NOA65 & NOA68. I am unable to find a technical data sheet besides the SDS. Please let me know if you can help.

There is some more information available on the Norland Products website: link here
 
NOA65: -15 to 60 C
 
NOA85: -80 to 90 C (aged) - You should read through this page for more information on aged vs. non-aged adhesive.
 
Please let me know if you have any further questions.

Case Title: CP33T/M Tolerance Information. Question: I’m working with a design that incorporates a threaded cage plate (PN: CP33T/M). This cage plate is mounted using 6 mm diameter dowel pins rather than the typical ER series cage rods. Would you be able to provide diameter tolerance information and position tolerance information (if available) for the four 6 mm diameter holes?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The four cage rods holes on the CP33T/M have a diameter tolerance of 0.2370" +0.0005" / -0.0000. The distance between the holes is 1.1811" +/- 0.0005". Hopefully this helps. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: F19SC1 torque. Question: I was viewing this part and I wanted to ask if there was a recommended or max torque value for this locking collar.

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support.

 

Unfortunately we do not spec a recommended torque. Outside of particularly demanding applications it is generally safe to tighten to "hand/finger tight" with a final amount of torsion to ensure the collar is seated securely.


Please contact me with any further questions.
Case Title: SLH1 Material. Question: I am inquiring about the material of the SLH1 Slide Spring Clamp, if there are any coatings on the spring arm etc.

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Tech Support. The material of the SLH1 is as follows:
 
Shoulder Screws: 316 Stainless Steel
Dowel Pins: Alloy Steel
Compression Springs: 300 series stainless steel
Spring Clips: 301 Full Hard Stainless Steel
 
I hope this helps! Feel free to contact me if you need more information.

Case Title: BK5. Question: I am looking at ‘BK5 - Black Nylon, Polyurethane-Coated Fabric, 5' x 9' (1.5 m x 2.7 m) x 0.005" (0.12 mm) Thick’. Is this material also highly absorbing for UV 275 nm? We need it as a safety protection for stray light from UV LEDs. I only saw the Reflection data on the black cardboards and some foils but not on this cloth.

 

Thorlabs - BK5 Black Nylon, Polyurethane-Coated Fabric, 5' x 9' (1.5 m x 2.7 m) x 0.005" (0.12 mm) Thick

Thank you very much for your inquiry. 
 
We have not tested this below 350 nm, so we cannot determine suitability at this time. 
 
Please note attachment for available  density and reflectance data.
 
Based on the data at 350 nm, I would not expect a significant change in density at 275 nm.
 
The BK5 Material is Polyurethane Coating on Weaved Nylon Fabric. 
 
Should you at any time have questions regarding an order or want to provide feedback about any of our products or service, please feel free to reach out to me personally or our service team.

I look forward to the opportunity to serve you again in the future.

Case Title: SM1L40. Question: I was just curious if this black material is reflective in the SWIR (1550nm)?

 

Thorlabs - SM1L40 SM1 Lens Tube, 4.00" Thread Depth, One Retaining Ring Included

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. I have attached reflectance data for our black anodized aluminum to this email. It will likely be around 5-12% depending on angle of incidence. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: FSR1. Question: Do you have any data on how much length of 900µm diameter fiber will fit into one FSR1 reel?
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The FSR1 can fit up to 5m in length of Ø900 µm or Ø3 mm fiber. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: RE: 91923. Question: Please send your CO for items below

Protective glasses for laser engraving machine range: 190- 450nm&800-2000nm – 1 pcs

Thank you for contacting us! Our selection of laser googles can be found under the following link: https://www.thorlabs.com/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=762. In order to decide on the right model, we kindly ask that you review the specifications of the goggles and your laser with your laser safety officer. It is their responsibility to determine the appropriate safety ratings depending on the laser and application. We are at your disposal if you have any questions about these items.

Case Title: RMSA1. Question: I'm just double checking the spec on the RMSA1 adapter.

We are fitting an Olympus RMS thread objective to a Leica microscope that has a nosepiece for 25mm objectives. 
Is this the correct adapter?

Thank you for your enquiry. The RMSA1 adapter is designed to act as an adapter between Internal M25x0.75 threads and external RMS threads. As your Olympus objective has an RMS thread (I would assume it is external) then that should be OK. Unfortunately we do not have all the information on the threads used in Leica Microscopes, and so I cannot comment as to whether this will be compatible. If you can verify that the Leica microscope has a M25x0.75 internal thread then this should be OK.

Case Title: Connection SMA1 to SMA905. Question: I am making a setup consisting of two SMA1 to multimode fibre connections, and I am looking for a method to directly connect a multimode optic fibre cable to an PM16-120 sensor.
I could not exactly find what I was looking for on the website. So I wanted to ask if you could help me identify the parts that in the pictures that I attached, or if there is another method to connect SMA905 to SM1.

thank you for your request. I would recommend the S120-SMA (Terminated Fiber Adapters (thorlabs.de)) to you. The fiber adapter has an SMA connector and an internal SM1 threading to attach it directly to the PM16-120.
What you have looks like a cage plate with two different threadings. We don’t have that article as a standard item. If there is no need to integrate the fiber adapter into a cage system, the S120-SMA is sufficient for your purpose. Otherwise, you can instead use the SM1SMA (Terminated Fiber Adapters (thorlabs.de)) and combine it with the CP33/M (Standard 30 mm Cage Plates (thorlabs.de)). The SM1SMA together with the CP33/M would then closely resemble your adapter. Please note, that the SM1SMA alone cannot be directly attached to the PM16-120. If you have any further questions, feel free to ask.

Case Title: Adapter M30x1 to SM2. Question: I would need an adapter with internal M30x1 thread to external SM2 thread. Actually, I’d like to mount a M30x1 externally threaded component into a 6axis K6X2 mount.

 

Could you please help with some suitable solution?

Thank you very much for your inquiry.
 
Unfortunately, we do not offer such an adapter with internal M30 x 1 thread. 
 
Please be so kind to let me know , which component with M30x 1 do you want to mount? Is it a product from  company Sill ? Part number ?
 
If it is from Sill, an adapter from M30x1 to C-mount should be available  from Sill. From C-mount to SM2 we can offer a solution
 
Our SM2A54 adapter has external SM2 (2.035"-40) threading and internal C-mount (1.00"-32) threading.
 
Should you at any time have questions regarding an order or want to provide feedback about any of our products or service, please feel free to reach out to me personally or our service team.

Case Title: XRNV1/M - Material question. Question: I have a question about the XRNV1/M stage:

Does it contain any copper (alloy) parts?

Thank you very much for your inquiry.
 
Yes, a few components are with Alloy material like Hardened Alloy Steel, Screws  Alloy, Black Ox also is used Phosphor Bronze, etc for gearbox parts.
 
To offer the stage with other materials is not possible to do!
 
Should you at any time have questions regarding an order or want to provide feedback about any of our products or service, please feel free to reach out to me personally or our service team.

Case Title: T12XYZ/M. Question: Hello, my name is Diego, I’m new working with stages and I have to mount a system to align a laser.

 

I’m trying to make a simulation of all the alignment systems, so I need to know the exact travel range of the T12XYZ, I assumed that from the nominal position we can notice in the PDF attached, the travel range would be 12,7/2 in each sense. Is that ok?

Hello Diego,

thank you for your request. Yes, that’s correct. In the drawing the T12XYZ has half its travel range in each direction.
If you have any further questions, feel free to ask.

With best regards

Case Title: SM1ZM. Question: We have an optical system where we would like to use the SM1ZM zoom housing, but the 25mm diameter lens we have is too thick for this housing (center thickness 12.5mm, edge thickness 11.56mm). Do you currently have a non-rotating zoom housing for this lens size? If not, what do you recommend using instead of the SM1ZM?

thank you for your enquiry.
 
I have found the perfect adjustable SM1 Lens tube for you, and it is the, "SM1U - Adjustable Collimation Adapter for Ø1" or Ø25 mm Optic."
 
And it can be found on the following webpage: https://www.thorlabs.de/thorproduct.cfm?partnumber=SM1U
 
It holds lenses with thickness up to 17.4 mm and it is non-rotating.
 
If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to ask me again, I will be more than happy to assist you.
 
Thank you and have a nice day!

Case Title: Linear polarizer mounting. Question: We are using some linear polarisers and we would just like to clarify the correct way to mount these.

 

We are currently using an SM1V05 lens tube with a linear polariser fitted, this needs to be clamped with a stress free lock ring which is what you recommend. However there is a statement on your website highlighted below that says they should not be mounted in set screw based mounts:



 

We are currently supporting this lens tube in a CP36 cage plate. Is this OK or will the locking set screw cause the polariser to experience problems?

Thank you for your enquiry. The CP36 set screw will touch the lens tube not the polariser, so this should be OK. I do not think you can over torque the screw to the point it deforms the tube and affects the polariser, this would be quite difficult to achieve! Even so the stress free RR should protect the polariser, you should still avoid over tightening it to protect the polariser.

Case Title: SM1D12SZ. Question: I’m trying to estimate how good the optical alignment is with a system where we pre-aligned to a pinhole in one of these irises. Could you give me sense on the tolerances involved? I.e. how well centred is the centre of this iris (we used it with a diameter of 2mm).

 

Also, if possible, can you help calculate how well centred this iris would be relative to a 30 mm cage system if it were mounted in a LCP33/M Cage Plate Adapter?

Thanks for your patience. Regarding the iris mounted on the LCP33/M. This cage adapter has its  middle centre at 35.3 mm +/- 0.25 mm, from each side, as seen on the CAD drawing. Regarding the iris, unfortunately we do not give a minimum aperture, so we do not have any tolerances for specific aperture diameters. Moreover, 2 mm in aperture will also need to be achieved manually so this could give a high uncertainty, and we do not have any value on this. Sorry about this. 

Lever Actuated, SM-Threaded Iris Diaphragms: https://www.thorlabs.com/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=220&pn=SM1D12SZ
Case Title: PRM2 torque. Question: Is there a specified drive torque on the micrometer adjustment?
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support. There is no specific drive torque for the micrometer adjustment.
Case Title: SM05LTRR. Question: Would you be able to clarify what the tolerance is on the Ø0.32in[Ø8.1mm] clear aperture.
The tolerance for this measurement is plus/minus 0.005 inches.  I hope that helps!
Case Title: TR75/M. Question: Is there a tolerance on the 12.7mm diameter of this post?
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The diameter of the post is 0.499" +0.000 / 0.002"(12.6746 mm +0.000 / -0.0508 mm).Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: CRM1 vs. CRM1T. Question: To whom it may concern,

CRM1 is obsolete and is replaced with CRM1T. What’s the difference between the two? What’s the lead time for CRM1T?

The two parts are very similar, but the CRM1T was redesigned to change the cage locking setscrew to use a 2mm (5/64in) Hex key instead of 1.3mm (.05 in) hex key so that it matched the rotation locking setscrew hex key.  In addition, both setscrews were changed to be M4x.7 thread.

Case Title: Mating sleeve thickness. Question: My name is Bruno, PhD student at the Technical University of Delft in the Imaging Physics department, Quantum Photonic Integration and Sensing group. Since we are thinking to use the mating sleeves to integrate in a fabrication step, we would like to know the thickness of it or what is the same, the radius of the inner diameter. Do you know the thickness of this element?

thank you for your request. You can have a look at some technical drawings if you click on the little document symbol left to the item number. There you can find for example CAD files in the PDF or Solidworks format. If you can’t find the information you are looking for, please tell me to which mating sleeve you are referring to. If you have any more questions, feel free to ask.

Case Title: LX30/M Specs. Question: Looking at drawings of the LX30/M I am not seeing M6 holes labeled to be at a 25mm spacing on the vertical face. It looks like they should be but it’s not labeled. Please confirm that there are holes at 25mm on the vertical face.

Thanks.

I looked at our more detailed drawings and confirmed the distance between the M6 holes is 25 mm.  Just so we are certain we are talking about the same holes, I have annotated a screenshot from the drawing on the website (we aren't permitted to share the detailed drawings with customers).  My annotations are in red.

Case Title: Polaris-P20. Question:  I was looking into using my current Polaris P-20 Piezoelectric actuators and was wondering if you have the following information.

Voltage vs Displacement Graphs
Working Graphs
Specific Piezoelectric Constants

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. We have some of this information, including the Voltage vs Displacement Graph, in our spec sheet.
 
Hopefully this helps answer some of your questions but let me know if there are still some specs you need and I will contact our manufacturing team to see if we have those specs. 
Feel free to contact me if you have any further questions or queries.

Case Title: AB90H moving load rating. Question: I came across your products and was curious what the moving load rating for the above item is? This bracket could be used as a part of a bike mount assembly that would be held above my truck bed.

Thanks for contacting Thorlabs. Unfortunately we haven't tested these brackets for a dynamic or static load rating. These brackets are generally intended for rigid, static optics setups and high loads were not factored in the design process. They are made from 6061-T6 Aluminum with a black anodized finish: MIL-A-8625, Type 2, Class 2; and you may be able to use the solid model of the part available on our site to simulate the material properties, however it is difficult to recommend our brackets for your application in particular. If you have any success with this application, we'd love to hear your feedback. Let me know if you have any questions!

Case Title: Small screws. Question: I am hoping you can help with a small problem. I have several filter holders: FH2. There are 4, small screws that hold the clips that secure the filter. The screws are small enough that, when loosened, they fall into the ¼-20 holes in my optical table to be lost forever. What size are these screws? Much appreciated.

Thanks for contacting Thorlabs. These are stainless steel screws, so you may be able to remove them from the table if you have a small magnet on a stick that can fit into the taps in case that's ever an issue. The screws used are Phillips pan head, Stainless steel 18-8 alloy, #2-56 x 3/16" type. The "#2" is the imperial diameter, "56" is the Threads per inch, and 3/16" is the length of screw shank. I've attached a link here where you can find some, as we don't carry these separately on our site: Machine screws, Phillips pan head, Stainless steel 18-8, #2-56 x 3/16". I hope this helps!
Case Title: MB12 Tolerance. Question: What are the positional tolerances of the screw hole pattern?
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The tolerance of the screw hole pattern on the MB12 is +/- 0.005.

Case Title: NOA81. Question: I intend to use this glue in an project I am working on.  But I would like to know wat which temperature the glue can be used and stored after glue-up ? I have look around you website but could not find the correct information.

I have found information about the storage temperature of the NOA81. This information can be found under the manufacturer's website: https://www.norlandprod.com/adhesives/NOA%2081.html. It states on the website, that the shelf life of the liquid is a minimum of 4 months from the date of shipment, refer to the package label for the actual expiration date, if stored in a cool (5 - 22° C), dark place in the original container. If refrigerated, allow the adhesive to come to room temperature prior to use. After curing the cured adhesives can withstand temperatures from -150°C to 125° C. I hope I have helped you today. If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to ask us again. We will be more than happy to help you.

Case Title: KM100T. Question: Could you send me the Autocad drawing for this part number

https://www.thorlabs.com/_sd.cfm?fileName=6634-E0W.dxf&partNumber=KM100T

It’s not opening on the site.

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support and our apologies on any inconvenience caused! If you continue to run into this issue, please use www.thorlabs.us to be able to view these files. For reference her is the  Autocad drawing for KM100T - https://www.thorlabs.us/_sd.cfm?fileName=6634-E0W.pdf&partNumber=KM100T.

Case Title: Fully block UV. Question: Are these materials able to fully block UV light from a typical longwave (375nm) and short wave (254nm) fluorescent UV lamp used for viewing mineral fluorescence?

Unfortunately we do not have transmission data for the TB4 or the TB5 for UV applications. I apologize for this inconvenience. Double-layering either will provide a more light-tight environment than using one layer alone.
Case Title: KF25C038. Question: Could you please send us the drawing of KF25C038 in pdf file? We failed to download from the website.
Thanks for contacting Thorlabs. Apologies that you could not download the file, please find it attached. Hope this helps.

Case Title: support documents. Question: I would like to download the support files concerning “SPW607 - Spanner Wrench”, but your servers are unavailable.

Is it possible to receive the supporting step file?

Case Title: CRM1T/M mount with WPH10M plate. Question: I would like to know if its possible to extract the half-wave plate of the WPH10M from its mount and simply place it in a CRM1T/M mount? In my system I don't have space to have both mounts, and I don't know if the WPH10M mount is a special mount for the plate inside.

Thank you for your enquiry. You can indeed remove the half-wave plate from its aluminium housing by unscrewing the 1 inch diameter retaining ring, using an appropriate spanner wrench for 1 inch retaining rings, and thereafter placing the wave plate in the CRM1T/M housing in between two 1 inch retaining rings to hold them together. We also sell the  "SM1PRR - SM1 (1.035"-40) Plastic Retaining Ring for Ø1" Lens Tubes and Mounts", especially for use with sensitive optics. If you need to buy an appropriate spanner wrench, then this weblink will help you: https://www.thorlabs.de/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=1430. Please be careful when handling the wave plate. More information about optics handling and care can be found under the following weblink: Optics Handling and Care Tutorial (thorlabs.com)

Case Title: Angle per revolution PR01 vs. XRR1. Question: 

 Just wanted to ask a question about two of your manual rotation stages.  The XRR1 calls out 5.7 mrad per revolution – what is the angle per revolution of the PRO1?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The PR01 uses our 148-206ST imperial micrometer, with 0.025" per revolution and 25 increments (for 0.001" of linear travel per increment). This linear motion can be approximated using trigonometry for the angular motion, so you can expect about 1° of rotation per revolution of the fine adjuster, or about 0.04° per increment. That said, the best determination of angular resolution would be using the Vernier scale engraved on the side of the stage to get down to 5 arcmin (0.083°). Hopefully this helps. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: Voice Coil: VC125/M. Question: I was wondering what the maximum current/voltage that the VC125/M voice coil can take? Also, if you could provide me with the number of wraps of the coil, that would be great.

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. For the VC125/M, we specify a max current .67 A at 60 °C and 1.45 A at 200 °C. With a coil resistance of 3.5 Ω, this corresponds to max voltages of 2.345 V and 5.075 V at those respective temperatures. Regarding amount of wraps of the coil, I am not sure of that. I will be looking into that and whether we can provide it and will get back to you once I have more information. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: Question on SM2D25. Question: Can you please tell me the angle of rotation of the lever required to actuate this iris through its full travel?
Thank you for your patience. The full angular range is about 117.926 degrees. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: Difference CXY1A vs CXY1?. Question: What’s the difference between the very recently discontinued CXY1 and the new CXY1A? The technical specs seem to be identical or am I missing something?

Thank you for contacting Thorlabs. The CXY1 and the CXY1A are essentially the same part. The only difference is that the CXY1A utilizes a M4 x 0.7 locking set screw with a 5/64" (2.0 mm) hex while the CXY1 had utilized a 4-40 locking set screw with a .05" (1.3 mm) hex. Please let us know if there are any further questions.
Case Title: NOA65. Question: Is NOA65 epoxy UHV compatible? Do you have data on its outgassing properties? Thank you.

Thank you very much for your inquiry.  We do not have our own measurement data for the outgassing of the NOA65. Outgassing is most often characterized by weight loss of the material.
 Outgassing by measuring Total Mass Loss (TML %), Collected Volatile Condensable Materials (CVCM %) and a reported value for Water Vapor Regain (WVR %).  Measurements are from NASA. https://outgassing.nasa.gov/

Case Title: TS2938426, Your Purchase Order CT2201171- reply requested. Question: Can you please assist with telling me the difference between LM1XY and LM1XY/M other than one is imperial and one is metric?

Apart from LM1XY being imperial and having a 8-32 mounting hole and LM1XY/M being metric and having a M4 x 0.7 mounting hole there is not much of a difference in the specs, they are both Translating Lens Mount for Ø1" Optics with 1 Retaining Ring Included. Here are the CAD drawings if customer would like to compare the two. LM1XY - https://www.thorlabs.us/_sd.cfm?fileName=0058-E0W.pdf&partNumber=LM1XY, LM1XY/M - https://www.thorlabs.us/_sd.cfm?fileName=3055-E0W.pdf&partNumber=LM1XY/M

Case Title: XRN25P/M with ZFS25B. Question: We have a manual linear stage XRN25P/M, but want to upgrade it to motorized. Would the actuator ZFS25B be compatible?

Looking at the drawings it appears possible, but wanted to double check with you.

Thank you for your e-mail and your interest in our products.
Yes, you can use the ZFS25B to motorize the XRN25P/M. Both have a travel range of 25 mm and a barrel with a 9.5 mm diameter. Also, the motor is small enough to not obstruct the movement or mounting of the stage.

Case Title: MS1S/M. Question: from datasheet this tool allows a 0.5mm movement per revolution. Which is the step resolution? And how many steps are there for each revolution? I can’t find it on the datasheet.

Thank you for your e-mail and your interest in our stages.
The MS1S/M is a manual stage with a micrometre screw. As you correctly said, one revolution of the micrometre results in 500 µm movement. The micrometre has engravings every 10 µm. Thus, you should be able to achieve a “resolution” of 10 µm.
There is no steps per revolution for this stage. It does not have a gear or something else that has steps. The stage has a spring against which you push it and bearings for smooth operation.
Case Title: HW-KIT2 in 316 stainless steel?. Question: I'm wondering if ThorLabs has a version of the HW-KIT2 - 1/4"=20 cap screw and hardware kit all in 316 stainless steel? Thanks,

Unfortunately we do not offer any 1/4"-20 hardware kits with screws made from 316 stainless steel, and I apologize for the inconvenience. These screws are made from 18-8 stainless steel. I would recommend taking a look at McMaster-Carr to see if they have 316 stainless steel hardware in stock.

Case Title: GNL10/M. Question: I wanted to know what the minimum incremental movement for these goniometers is.  GNL10/M and GNL18/M

The GNL10/M and GNL18/M both have an accuracy of 10 arcmin or 0.167°.
 
The accuracy of the two goniometers correspond to the vernier scale on the sides. If you look at the bottom scale of the goniometers, you will see a span of 0 to 60 on both sides. Each interval corresponds to the aforementioned 10 arcmin and 60 arcmin equals 1 degree. The top scale corresponds to the actual degree deviation of the goniometer's surface, which will be 0 to 10 degrees on the GNL10, and 0 to 5 degrees on the GNL18.
 
Here is a helpful guide on how to interpret the markings of the vernier scale.: https://www.thorlabs.com/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=2464&tabname=Vernier%20Scales.
 
Should you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to ask me again, I will be more than happy to assist you.
Case Title: LG10A. Question: we would like to purchase two pairs of LG10 Goggles. Could you please suggest which of the types A,B,C is more suitable to wear together with myopia glasses?

Case Title: Inquiry about connecting VA100C/M to CRM1T/M. Question: I want to attach VA100C/M to CRM1T/M without poles in cages to rate the variable slit with CRM1T/M. Then, I'm looking for adaptors to connect a hole of 25 mm in diameter (CRM1T/M) to a hole of 12 mm in diameter (in VA100C/M). Do you have item something like that?

you could use an SM05A3 (Adapter with External SM05 Threads and External SM1 Threads) to achieve this. You would screw it into the two components to hold them together. If you need to align it with the zero mark then I would suggest screwing it in most of the way and then adjusting the position of the retaining ring in the CRM1T/M, from behind, using an SPW602 spanner wrench.

Case Title: PY005 Specs. Question: I am asking what is the minimum distance I can move the stage up? The minimum increment ( in micrometer) on the screw?

We do not have a spec for this. This depends on how far you would turn the screw. One full turn is 146.5 um of translation. If you were to perform half a turn, that would give you 78.25 um. It ultimately comes down to what fraction of a full turn you adjust it. The actuator does not have any sort of scale or engraving. Please let us know if there are any further questions.

Case Title: TS10. Question: I have questions regarding Torr Seal. I want to use it to seal small
cracks that should be vacuum-tight at high temperatures afterwards. What
is the highest recommended operating temperature? And is there any
information available what happens to Torr Seal at higher temperatures?

For the TS10 we have only the Vendor information available.  We have no experience for higher temperatures !
Temperature - 45° C to 120° C; cracks at LN2 temperatures
 
Torr Seal epoxy resin quickly seals leaks on any type of vacuum system or component,  Torr Seal is solvent free and can be used at pressures of  of 10^-9 Torr (mbar) and below, at temperatures from -45° C to 120° C (bakeable temperature).
 
Additionally, Torr Seal permits leak checking immediately after curing and bonds with many materials including metal, ceramic, and glass.
Case Title: SH6MS10. Question: Could I kindly enquire for your SH6MS10 Screws, what grade of stainless steel are they?
Thank you for contacting Thorlabs Technical Support! I believe these screws are made out of 303 grade Stainless Steel.

Case Title: FW: Laser Safety Glasses 2-5µm. Question: We are looking to buy some laser safety glasses wot work with lasers from 2µm to 5µm, from looking at the Thorlabs website it seems the LG11 model would be best, though the optical density graph cuts off at 3µm. Could you confirm this would be the best set of glasses for working with 2µm-5µm lasers or provided some suggestions as to a better model.

Thanks for your message. Determining whether a certain product is suitable for a specific laser setup requires a detailed on-site evaluation of the conditions (laser type, beam path etc.). This is part of the responsibility of the laser safety officer of your organisation. They have to evaluate the local situation and define the needed laser safety class (called "L"-rating according to the European Standard EN207) for the goggles. Based on that information the product can be chosen. We - as a reseller of these laser glasses - cannot take over any responsibility for the correct selection based on descriptive information of a setup or laser. Since we do not offer on-site evaluations, we cannot state that a certain item is suitable and sufficient for a certain application, neither can we recommend an item from our side.
 
Once your safety officer has defined the needed L-rating for the goggles we will be happy checking if we can offer a suitable product. Copies of the EN207 certificates are available as well (pdf format).
 
Once you have selected the correct laser glasses then I will be happy to forward you a quotation. Please contact us if you have any further queries.

Laser Safety Glasses: https://www.thorlabs.com/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=762
Case Title: RCA1. Question: I want to use RCA1 for parts 1 and 2. My system will weigh about 1000 grams. Is it enough to use 2 pieces, can it carry this weight?

Thank you very much for your inquiry.
 
The ~ 1000 gr are not a problem.  It could become critical from approx. > 3 or 4 kg.
Each RCA1 used 4 times M4 set screws for mounting on ERxx Rods.  Also the Clamp Locking Screws on the  dovetail bracket hold this weight.
 
They hold this weight without any problems.

Case Title: Kinematic Base Rods/Rollers. Question: For some time I have been wondering about the rods/rollers from the bottom part of the kinematic base, which keep the balls and the top part in their position. See the part highlighted in the attached image. How are these rollers put into position (for example in the KB1X1 Kinematic Base). Are these rollers fixed or movable, and can they be removed? If they are fixed, could you provide some details on how they are mounted?

Thank you for your enquiry.
 
I have taken a look at the assembly plans of the KB1X1, and the dowels (or rollers as you said) are arbor pressed into their respective H-patterns on the bottom plate of the KB1X1. The dowels are therefore immovable and are fixed.
 
The ball bearings are super glued into their places, while the strong magnets are epoxied using a combination of Loctite 7649 and Loctite 680.
 
I hope I have answered your question. Please do not hesitate to ask me again, should you have any further.
